title: Trump to Issue Travel Advisory for N.Y. Region, Backing Off Quarantine Threat
summary:
WASHINGTON — President Trump said Saturday night that he would not impose a quarantine on New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, but would instead issue a “strong” travel advisory for the region to be enacted by the governors of the three states.
Mr. Trump had offered no details about how his administration would enforce a ban on movements in and out of the three northeastern states, including the country’s most populous city, and the idea drew swift condemnation.
Andrew M. Cuomo of New York called it a “declaration of war on states,” and Gov.
Ned Lamont of Connecticut said it could cause confusion and panic.
The president appeared to heed those warnings, abruptly abandoning a proposal that he had floated with no notice on Saturday morning, once again subjecting the country — and, in particular, people in the northeast — to mixed messages about what his administration believed was necessary to defeat the dangerous pathogen.

title: Bernice Lambert Pegram, 94, former medical technologist at DePaul Hospital and DOD Naval Station Norfolk
summary:
Bernice Lambert PegramBernice Lambert Pegram, 94, passed away Monday, April 6, 2020, in the Hoy Center at Westminster-Canterbury on the Bay.
Her career included working as a laboratory analyst for World War II efforts, teaching high school chemistry and serving as a medical technologist at DePaul Hospital and DOD Naval Station Norfolk.
Left to cherish her memory are her beloved husband of 64 years, George Worthy Pegram Jr.; three daughters, Jan DeAngelo (Bob), Jill Genier (Glenn) and Joan Thornhill (Jim); son, George W. Pegram III (Roxanne); two sisters, Abbie Amos and Joan McGirt; and 10 grandchildren.
A private family graveside service will be held at Riverside Cemetery, Norfolk, with a memorial service to be held at a later date when we can all be together.
In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Foodbank of Southeastern Virginia, 800 Tidewater Drive, Norfolk, VA 23504.

title: Residents file lawsuit to try and stop Norfolk’s St. Paul’s redevelopment plan
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. - Residents have filed a federal lawsuit to try and make the city come up with a new plan for the redevelopment of the St. Paul's area.

The lawsuit was filed by residents Evonne Bryant, Sylvia Givens, Conswayla Simmons, Residents of St. Paul's Quadrant Tenant Group and New Virginia Majority against Norfolk, Norfolk Redevelopment and Housing Authority, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and HUD Sec.

summary:

Grocery giant Aldi is opening its second location in the city on Thursday, just over a month after opening its first on Military Highway.
The chain says its goal is to become the nation's third-largest grocery retailer by the end of 2022.
The first 100 customers to enter the new Norfolk location will receive a "golden ticket" containing gift cards ranging from $10 to $100.
First-day shoppers can also enter for a chance to win a year's supply of produce.

title: Norfolk residents demand City Council draft 2nd Amendment resolution
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. (WAVY) – Gun rights took center stage at the Norfolk City Council meeting Tuesday night.
Second Amendment advocates say their message remains the same — they want city leaders to declare Norfolk a Second Amendment Sanctuary city.
Several people demanded action and ultimately protection from the laws they say are an attack on their constitutional rights.
Some have passed resolutions simply in support of citizens’ Second Amendment rights, while others have said discussions on gun laws belong in Richmond.
Here’s the rundown on where area localities stand:

title: Norfolk PD New Year’s resolution: Improve officer wellness and resiliency
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. (WAVY) – In spring 2020, the Norfolk Police Department will start an evidence-based wellness program that will be provided to all sworn members of the department.
The police department partnered with the Bureau of Justice Assistance, International Association of Chiefs of Police, and University of Pennsylvania in December 2018.
Norfolk PD became the first law enforcement agency in Virginia to receive nationally-accredited wellness and resiliency training.
“The women and men of the Norfolk Police Department are faced with stressful and critical challenges each day,” said Norfolk Police Chief Larry D. Boone in a news release.
In November, 10 officers also attended the VALOR Resilience Train-the-Trainer Program to begin the implementation of this program throughout the department.

title: Friend of I-64 homicide victim in ‘disbelief’ as loved ones search for answers
summary:
“He loved his kids,” friend Christopher Patterson said.
He loved kids in general.”The 40-year-old from Virginia Beach, better known by family and friends as "Bake" or "Kee-Kee," died Sunday afternoon.
According to Virginia State Police, someone shot into a car Baker and two other men were riding in early Friday morning on I-64 eastbound.
Patterson told News 3 reporter Brian Hill that he has spoken with Baker’s immediate family and they are still distraught knowing no one has been arrested.
If you can help bring Baker’s loved ones closure, call Virginia State Police at (757) 424-6800 or visit this link.

title: Letters for April 6
summary:
Two weeks after the president's declaration the governor on March 28 makes a request for the regional test site.
In all this time, I would like to know what the health care professionals of the state and the Virginia Division of Consolidated Laboratory Services have done to stand up test sites throughout the commonwealth.
As a non-physician, I would assume testing and detection would be paramount in a pandemic, followed by isolation or quarantine and treatment.
Testing sites may be plentiful, but it would be reassuring if the governor would make information public.

summary:
NORFOLK, Va. (WAVY) — Gun rights took center stage at the Norfolk City Council meeting Tuesday night.
There’s no official sanctuary city resolution on the table, but that didn’t stop people from arguing their case any less.
“We’re asking to make Norfolk a Second Amendment sanctuary.
A city spokeswoman says it’s up to council whether a Second Amendment sanctuary resolution happens.
Some have passed resolutions simply in support of citizens’ Second Amendment rights, while others have said discussions on gun laws belong in Richmond.

title: Hampton Roads Diversity and Inclusion Consortium receives FBI award
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. (WAVY) – The U.S. Department of Justice announced the Hampton Roads Diversity and Inclusion Consortium (HRDIC) has been selected for a 2019 Director’s Community Leadership Award.
It was announced by Martin Culbreth, special agent in charge of the FBI’s Norfolk Field Office, for the HRDIC’s commitment to civil rights and inclusion.
The FBI Director’s Community Leadership Award is an annual award that recognizes individuals and organizations that make extraordinary contributions to education and the prevention of crime and violence in their communities.
HRDIC will be informally recognized by Special Agent in Charge Martin Culbreth on Thursday, Jan. 9 at 10 a.m. at the Norfolk Field Office.
HRDIC executive director and HRDIC chair will receive the award from FBI Director in a ceremony in May at FBI Headquarters, Washington, DC.

title: 26 restaurants in Downtown Norfolk offer special pricing, menus for restaurant week
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. (WAVY) — Those who have been wanting to try out some new restaurants in Downtown Norfolk may find some deals during Downtown Norfolk Restaurant Week.
Restaurant week will run from Jan. 19 to 26, Downtown Norfolk wrote in a news release.
There are 26 participating restaurants, which will offer price-fixed, multi-course dinners for $35 or $25, and lunch or brunch for $12.
“Downtown chefs are getting creative with offerings that range from coconut curry mussels to vegan bolognese” said Jessica Kliner, director of marketing and communications for Downtown Norfolk Council.
“Downtown Norfolk Restaurant Week is the perfect time explore the many restaurants here and get a taste of everything Downtown has to offer.”Get more information on participating restaurants at DowntownNorfolk.org.

title: 3 people arrested after Virginia Beach shooting, police chase
summary:
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. – The Virginia Beach Police Department arrested two men and one juvenile who were involved in a shooting Wednesday afternoon.
According to police, 23-year-old Norfolk man Christian Micah Harris and 23-year-old Virginia Beach man Datwan Lamont Bowden were arrested.
Both men were charged with robbery, use of a firearm, felonious assault and conspiracy, and are being held in the Virginia Beach Correctional Center without bond.
The juvenile is being held in the Virginia Beach Juvenile Detention Center.

title: Norfolk man wanted in connection with multiple larcenies at businesses, schools
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. (WAVY) — Norfolk police are looking for a man wanted in a string of larcenies across the city.
Investigators say 48-year-old William Broughton is targeting businesses, schools and even hospitals to steal from unsuspecting victims.
Along with the smoke shop, police have also taken larceny reports at Eastern Virginia Medical School, Tidewater Community College, Sentara Norfolk, Sentara Leigh, Depaul and Lake Taylor hospitals.
The employee WAVY.com talked to said she remembers seeing Broughton pacing around the store.
Broughton is wanted for six felony charges including credit card theft, credit card forgery, and credit card fraud.

title: January 2020 Carrier of the Month: USS John C. Stennis
summary:
NAVAL STATION NORFOLK, Va. - News 3 is honoring the crew of the USS John C. Stennis, the Carrier of the Month for January 2020.
The ship was commissioned in 1995 and remained in Norfolk until 1998, when it moved to the west coast.
Fresh off a combat deployment, the USS John C. Stennis returned to Norfolk in May, coming from Bremerton, Washington.
Now parked at Naval Station Norfolk, the ship is readying for a 4-year maintenance period.
WTKR News 3 is proud to honor the USS John C. Stennis as the January 2020 Carrier of the Month.

summary:

title: Virginia Beach psychiatrist sentenced for healthcare fraud scheme
summary:
According to the Department of Justice, 64-year-old Udaya K. Shetty agreed to pay more than $1 million to settle related civil claims.
Shetty was a licensed psychiatrist practicing medicine at his own practice, Behavioral & Neuropsychiatric Group, according to court records.
While at the practice, Shetty and one of his former employees, Mary Otto, engaged in a similar scheme.
The DOJ says although other Quietly Radiant staff members were responsible for billing, Shetty directed Otto to access the billing system and change all of his billing data to a higher billing rate.
Otto pleaded guilty for her role in the scheme and was sentenced to 15 months in prison on Jan. 10.

summary:

summary:

Police said 41-year-old Dominique D. Brown is charged with one count of abduction in connection with the barricade situation, police wrote in a news release around 3:30 p.m. Thursday.

Norfolk police take a man into custody following an hours-long barricade situation Thursday morning on Wellington Street.

summary:

Detectives found the man, 19-year-old Christopher M. Dunlap, and arrested him in Virginia Beach.
Thursday night, police said 14-year-old Sincerity Ennels and 15-year-old Emily Morrison have been found and have returned home safe.

title: Group plans to petition Norfolk City Council to force discussion on 2nd Amendment sanctuary issue
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. (WAVY) — A group plans petition Norfolk City Council to prompt the body to discuss a Second Amendment sanctuary-related ordinance proposal.
The chairman of the local Republican party announced Tuesday during a council meeting that he will file a petition Wednesday to force council to discuss and vote on the issue.
The petition requests City Council to consider and adopt a “Second Amendment Preservation Ordinance.”If petitioners get 1,250 signatures in 30 days, council will be required to hold public hearings on the ordinance.
The petition is a move the Republican party chair says he felt forced to do after he says Norfolk City Council has ignored the residents.
Well over 20 people spoke in support of Norfolk becoming a Second Amendment constitutional or sanctuary city.

title: New South Norfolk Jordan Bridge tolls start January 1
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. — South Norfolk Jordan Bridge (SNJB) officials on Monday announced new toll rates effective Wednesday, Jan. 1, 2020.
The Elizabeth River crossing will continue to offer the lowest rate to drivers who travel with a valid E-ZPass account.
Off-peak rates apply during all other weekday hours, weekends and select federal holidays (New Year's Day, Memorial Day, July 4th/Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day).
"Our base toll rate increases just ten cents per trip in the new year," says General Manager Kevin Crum.
"Our modest annual toll increase allows us to maintain a reliable river crossing at all times and meet financial obligations while absorbing elevated operational costs."

title: Norfolk event introduces citizens to volunteer opportunities
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. (WAVY) -- A Norfolk Chick-fil-A is offering free food to people who donate 10 or more hand-sewn face masks to a local children's hospital.
Chick-fil-A Ghent, located at 1600 Monticello Ave., is collecting hand-sewn face masks for adults and children at the Children's Hospital of the King's Daughters.
The children's hospital is in need of between 3,000 and 5,000 hand-sewn masks in adult and pediatric sizes during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Victim identified after off-duty Norfolk Police officer involved in Chesapeake shooting
summary:
CHESAPEAKE, Va. - Chesapeake Police responded to a shooting that involved an off-duty Norfolk Police officer Sunday.
On Tuesday, police identified the victim as 42-year-old Kelvin White from Chesapeake.
Officials say, an off-duty Norfolk police officer was contacted by a family member stating that a man allegedly threatened the family member with a weapon.
Police say that the off-duty officer identified himself to White before the shooting.
The Norfolk police internal affairs department will assist the Chesapeake police department in the investigation.

title: Norfolk, Virginia Beach mail collection boxes broken into, US Postal Inspection Service investigating
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. – Police are investigating after mail was recently stolen from mail collection boxes.
According to the US Postal Inspection Service, mail collection boxes were pried open at Janaf Shopping Center in Norfolk and at the Acredale Station Office on Kempsville Road in Virginia Beach.
Officials say it happened sometime late Sunday or early Monday morning and there is indication that mail was stolen.
The collection boxes have been taken out of service until officials say they’re secured so this doesn’t happen again.
Anyone with information or who believes they may have been a victim is asked to call the US Postal Inspection Service hotline at 877-876-2455.

title: International Class A Tall Ships coming to Norfolk in 2020
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. – Three tall ships from the International Class A group of Naval sail training ships are coming to Downtown Norfolk this year!
Norfolk Festevents says that the ships coming will include the Statsraad Lehmkuhl of Norway, Bae Guayas of Ecuador and Capitan Miranda of Uruguay.
Built in 1914 as a training ship for the German merchant marines, the Statsraad Lehmkuhl is a three-masted steel barque sail training vessel.
The ship’s visit marks the second consecutive year that the Capitan Miranda has visited Norfolk.
With its colorful sunburst sails, Capitan Miranda has won the “Most Spirit” award at many previous tall ship festivals around the world.

title: Former MMA fighter accused of strangling woman in Norfolk turns himself in
summary:
Brian “The Lion” Collette, 32, turned himself in to authorities.
He was wanted for Aggravated Assault stemming from an incident that occurred in Norfolk on Jan. 28.
Marshals and the Norfolk Police Department have taken a former professional MMA fighter wanted for allegedly strangling a woman last month into custody.
Brian “The Lion” Collette, 32, turned himself in on Tuesday after an outstanding arrest warrant against him was put out for Aggravated Assault for an incident that occurred in Norfolk on Jan. 28.

title: Carnival Cruise lines cancels all stops through June, including Norfolk
summary:
Nauticus officials say Norfolk's economy will miss out on potentially "hundreds of thousands of dollars" thanks to COVID-19.
NORFOLK, Va. — Before COVID-19, Nauticus executive director Stephen Kirkland said his team was gearing up for a booming cruise season.
But the world’s largest cruise company, Carnival Corporation, announced it’s canceling all of its sailings through June 26.
“Without questions, hundreds of thousands of dollars in terms of impact and direct revenues and frankly more significant than that is the indirect economic spin-off that these cruise ships have,” he said.
Kirkland explained the cruise industry is big business for cities that have ports of call.

title: VA: Hampton Roads Transit ridership drops 40% as people stay home amid coronavirus outbreak
summary:
Far fewer riders are taking Hampton Roads Transit’s buses, light rails and ferries over the past two weeks.
The average ridership has dropped by about 40% since March 9, before the coronavirus reached Hampton Roads and everything started to change.
Some people, working in essential businesses, still have to take public transportation and Hampton Roads Transit has taken some extra steps to stem the spread of the coronavirus during the outbreak.
Over the weekend, Hampton Roads Transit decided to make some seats on the buses unavailable, tying up folding seats in the front to help establish social distancing rules.
Otherwise, Hampton Roads Transit is operating under normal levels at this time.

title: A Norfolk gym is at a loss as it, and countless other businesses try to survive. Where do they turn?
summary:
The reason why dates back to the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.
There wasn’t a specific exemption for “terrorism” in business insurance policies, so when terrorists flew planes into the World Trade Center towers, the Pentagon and a field in Pennsylvania, insurance companies couldn’t afford to cover the mounting damages.
After being bailed out, the industry began writing policies that made an exemption for terrorism, and for viruses and pandemics, because it realized there was no way to calculate the price for those potential losses, either.
Businesses can still get terrorism coverage, but any losses claimed are guaranteed by the federal government as part of the Terrorism Risk and Insurance Act.

title: Friday the 13th is today, 13 weeks since the last one
summary:
Friday, March 13, 2020, is exactly 13 weeks since the last Friday the 13th -- December 13, 2019.
Oddly enough, that's another leap year, but the leap day will have nothing to do with it.
Back in 2012, there were three Friday the 13th that were 13 weeks apart.
That would be 13 days after Halloween which is on October 31.
Having Friday the 13th exactly 13 weeks apart isn't the only holiday-related quirk caused by this year's leap day.

title: Virginia to be home to deepest port on the East Coast
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. – The effort to make The Port of Virginia the deepest port on the U.S. East Coast will begin around January 2020, following the finalization of a contract with an international dredging firm that will take on the project’s initial phase.
On October 9, John F. Reinhart, CEO and executive director of the Virginia Port Authority, signed a contract with New Jersey-based Weeks Marine to begin the deepening of the western side of the Thimble Shoal Channel.
The work includes dredging the shipping channels to 55 feet – with deeper ocean approaches – and widening the channel to more than 1,400 feet in specific areas.
“When the work is complete, Virginia will be the only East Coast port with this capability,” Reinhart said.
“This project, combined with the $750 million we are investing to increase container capacity by 1 million units per year, sets up Virginia to be the premier gateway for trade on the East Coast.

title: Coronavirus: U.S. Navy Hospital Ships To Deploy To New York, West Coast
summary:
Coronavirus: U.S. Navy Hospital Ships To Deploy To New York, West CoastEnlarge this image toggle caption Alex Wong/Getty Images Alex Wong/Getty ImagesUpdated at 2:27 p.m.
ETA pair of U.S. Navy hospital ships will be deployed to New York and the West Coast, where medical workers are anxiously expecting a major influx of patients as the coronavirus spreads.
President Trump announced the plans for deployment during a news conference Wednesday, and New York Gov.
Andrew Cuomo confirmed that he expects one of those ships — the USNS Comfort — to take up a position in New York Harbor, adjacent to New York City.
He said the ship's presence will help take pressure off facilities and staff in New York state, which is expecting to need more than 50,000 new hospital beds and more than 30,000 new ventilators as the coronavirus spreads.

title: 'Salt contamination' to blame for sporadic power outages impacting 46,000 customers in Hampton Roads
summary:
Tens of thousands of Dominion Power customers in the area woke up Tuesday morning to find themselves without power.
NORFOLK, Virginia — The number of Dominion Power customers in Hampton Roads affected by sporadic power outages climbed to more than 46,000 throughout the day on Tuesday.
According to Dominion Power spokesperson Bonita Harris, most of those customers lost power due to rain mixing with salt and grime buildup on equipment during a time when the entire region went nearly an entire month without rain.
At different points throughout Tuesday morning and afternoon, up to 22,700 customers in Virginia Beach lost power as well as 10,800 customers in Norfolk and 1,000 on the Peninsula.
About 8,400 customers are still in the dark, including 850 customers in Norfolk, 6,600 in Virginia Beach, and 975 customers in Portsmouth.

title: Indicted ex-Norfolk Sheriff McCabe arrested, appears in court

The growth stems in part from increased federal spending in the military heavy region and a continued expansion of the coastal tourism industry.

A company ranks the best or the worst cities in America in a particular category, and a lot of times the research isn’t very credible or thorough.
However, WalletHub’s most recent list of the Most Sinful Cities in America dives into the details, and several local cities ranked low on the list, which is good.
Chesapeake and Virginia Beach did really well in almost every category.
They’re two of the least sinful cities in America, with Virginia Beach coming in at 179 and Chesapeake ranking 180 out of 182 cities!
So what’s the most sinful city in America?

title: JLARC to present report on casino gaming in Virginia
summary:
The state's legislative watchdog agency will release a report that reviews casino gaming laws in other states.
RICHMOND, Va. — The Joint Legislative Audit and Review Commission is set to present reports on Monday on the impact of casino gaming in the state of Virginia.
The 2019 General Assembly passed a bill authorizing casino gaming in five cities, including Norfolk and Portsmouth.
The reports are expected to detail how much money could be made from casino gaming, expanded gaming on the Virginia Lottery, as well as live horse racing and charitable gaming.
Last week, Portsmouth announced a partnership with Rush Gaming furthering its chances of being the first city in Hampton Roads to build a casino gaming venue.

title: New Lidl to open in Virginia Beach
summary:
The first 100 customers will be presented with a gift card ranging from $5 to $100.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. — Lidl announced it will open its newest store in Virginia on Wednesday, November 13.
The Virginia Beach store will be Lidl’s fourth in the city and tenth in Hampton Roads.
“We look forward to expanding our presence in Virginia Beach and getting to know even more customers in the community,” said Virginia Beach Store Manager Dani Perdue.
Shoppers can get free samples of an array of Lidl’s products and a complimentary Lidl reusable bag while supplies last.

title: Man seriously injured after being hit by truck in Downtown Norfolk
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. – A 69-year-old Portsmouth man was seriously injured when a 2008 Ford F-150 truck struck him around 12:30 a.m. Tuesday on St. Paul’s Boulevard at the intersection of East Brambleton Boulevard.
Police have said the man was not walking in the crosswalk area when he tried crossing in front of the truck that had a green light, and the right-of-way.
The man has been taken to Sentara Norfolk General Hospital for his injuries.
Traffic was impacted on St. Paul’s Boulevard for multiple hours due to the crash.
While alcohol and speed were not contributing factors in the crash, police are still investigating what happened.

title: Virginia Zoo: Baby orangutan Sofie died
summary:
The zoo said despite almost a full week of highly intensive 24-hour around the clock treatment and supportive care, the young orangutan died.
NORFOLK, Va. — The Virginia Zoo announced on Monday that the baby orangutan Sofie passed away.
The zoo said despite almost a full week of highly intensive 24-hour around the clock treatment and supportive care, the young year and a half old orangutan died.
Veterinary and animal care staff had been providing critical life support and treatment since last Monday to the baby due to a severe infection that affected several critical body functions.
Sofie touched the hearts of so many and countless others were inspired to care about orangutans and their conservation just by seeing her.

title: Duck Donuts to open new location in Norfolk
summary:
A grand opening for the newest Hampton Roads Duck Donuts franchise will be on November 9!
NORFOLK, Va. — Duck Donuts announced on Tuesday that a grand opening for the newest Hampton Roads franchise in Norfolk is set for Saturday, November 9.
Duck Donuts said the 1st, 25th, 50th and 100th customers in line will win free donuts for a year!
“We are thrilled to be opening our second Duck Donuts location and our first in Norfolk, the city home to the largest Naval Port in the world,” said Chris Torio.
On top of donuts, the Norfolk location also serves Duck Donuts’ signature coffee blends including the Riptide Roast, Light House Blend, and Sunset Pier Decaf, espresso, donut breakfast sandwiches, donut sundaes, new menu items including frozen beverages and milkshakes, select retail items and more.

title: Sentara Norfolk General Hospital's cafe donating unused food to local soup kitchens
summary:
The cafe's operator partnered with the Food Bank of Southeastern Virginia and the Eastern Shore in the food rescue program that provides unusedNORFOLK, Va. — The Retreat Café at Sentara Norfolk General Hospital is donating its prepared and unused food to local soup kitchens.
Morrison Healthcare, operator of the cafe, partnered with the Food Bank of Southeastern Virginia and the Eastern Shore in the food rescue program that provides unused hot food for use to area soup kitchens.
The prepared, unused food is taken to a soup kitchen at the Basilica of St. Mary.
The pans of unused cafeteria foods are safely chilled or frozen and picked up by the Food Bank’s ‘Food Rescue’ program.
"About 171,000 people in Hampton Roads are food insecure,” says Jessica Melton, COO of Sentara Norfolk General Hospital.

title: Norfolk Airport: Decrease in passengers in November
summary:
There were only 320,154 passengers that traveled through the Norfolk International Airport in 2019 compared to 2018's 324,646 passenger count.
NORFOLK, Va. — Norfolk International Airport (ORF) saw about 4,400 fewer passengers in November compared to 2018.
However, from January to November 2019, the total passenger count has increased by 7.76 percent reaching 3,641,871 passengers versus 3,379,746 passengers during the same period in 2018.
January to November 2019 cargo pounds shipped have decreased 1.03 percent representing 58,564,152 cargo pounds versus 59,176,008 cargo pounds during the same period in 2018.
Norfolk International Airport is the major airport serving Coastal Virginia and Northeast North Carolina with scheduled air service provided by Allegiant, American, Delta, Frontier, Southwest, United, and their affiliate airline partners.

title: Northam announces trade plan, education grant during visit to Norfolk
summary:
Ralph Northam gave keynote remarks at the Virginia Conference on World Trade, and also made an announcement about education at ODU.
NORFOLK, Va. — Virginia Governor Ralph Northam paid a visit to the Mermaid City on Wednesday.
Northam gave keynote remarks at the Virginia Conference on World Trade, where he announced the Commonwealth's first comprehensive international trade strategic plan.
It lays out an aggressive goal to expand Virginia's international trade output by 50 percent over the next 15 years.
“Economic development will continue to be very important to us, education, healthcare is very important, renewable energy,” he said.

title: TSA stops Virginia Beach woman with loaded handgun at Norfolk International Airport
summary:
This marks the 14th gun TSA officers detected at the Norfolk airport so far in 2019.
NORFOLK, Va. — Police cited a Virginia Beach woman on state weapons charges after a TSA officer found a loaded handgun in her carry-on bag.
A TSA officer monitoring the checkpoint X-ray machine detected a .25-caliber handgun with six bullets in a travel bag.
This marks the 14th gun TSA officers detected at the Norfolk airport so far this year.
TSA officials notified airport police, who responded to the checkpoint, confiscated the gun and cited the woman on weapons charges.

title: Group that filed petition to repeal original vote on Norfolk casino collects 3,400 signatures in a day
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. – The group that filed a petition to repeal the original vote on the proposed casino in Norfolk announced Thursday they have collected more than 3,400 signatures in one day.
The Citizens for an Informed Norfolk Committee says the signatures were all collected on Tuesday, November 5, which was Election Day.
A month after the council’s vote, the group Say NO to the Norfolk Casino announced they failed to get enough signatures on their petition calling for a referendum.
The petition was filed with the Norfolk City Clerk’s office pursuant to Section 31 of the Norfolk City Charter and will be presented to the city council on November 26.
“As petitioners, we created Informed Norfolk in order for residents to better understand and be informed about the impacts of a casino in Norfolk.

title: IKEA Norfolk to hold veteran, military appreciation event over Veterans Day weekend
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. – IKEA Norfolk will honor local military heroes over Veterans Day weekend with deals, giveaways and its Veterans and Military Appreciation Event.
According to a release by IKEA Norfolk, veterans and active-duty military with a valid ID can eat free at the store’s restaurant from Saturday, November 9 to Monday, November 11.
Then on Veterans Day, Monday, November 11, veterans, active-duty military and their families are invited in-store for an all-day event beginning with gifts to the first veterans and active-duty military in line.
The first 100 veterans and active-duty military in line with a valid ID will receive a free picture frame.
“We recognize the dedication and sacrifices made by our nation’s veterans and service members,” said IKEA Norfolk Loyalty Manager Michelle Stephenson-White.

title: New drug statistics reveal how the opioid epidemic grew in Hampton Roads
summary:
Data collected due to national lawsuits shows how drug distribution spiked in local cities and which pharmacies were tasked with filling the most prescriptions.
Specifically, the number of oxycodone prescriptions sent to Denbigh Pharmacy doubled in those 6 years, illustrating the birth of the national opioid crisis.
In Portsmouth, a CVS-owned company named Omnicare, which supplies opioids to nursing homes throughout Hampton Roads, filled the strongest prescriptions.
And in Chesapeake, Lawrence Pharmacy filled twice as many doses than any other drugstore in the city.
They simply filled prescriptions written by doctors, who responded to a push for opioid treatments from drug manufacturers, distributors, patients and other sources.

summary:
NORFOLK, Va. – A man and woman have been charged in connection with a deadly shooting that happened Wednesday.
34-year-old Jermaine Tucker and 25-year-old Tkeyah Bell were charged.
Tucker has been charged with with Second Degree Murder and Use of a Firearm and Bell has been charged with accessory after the fact.
The shooting happened in the 5000 block of E. Princess Anne Road around 10:15 p.m.

Travis’s stepfather says the young boy was asleep on the couch downstairs when a bullet came flying through the house.
Keisha Edwards works at Minority Aids Support Services in Norfolk, just steps away from where the shooting happened.

title: Hampton Roads rebrands itself 'The 757'
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. — The Hampton Roads Chamber announced it wants to rebrand the Hampton Roads region into "757."
The area has had many names throughout the years including Hampton Roads, Tidewater, Coastal Virginia, Southeast Virginia and Norportapeake Beach.
Envision 2020 reported that "757" is a regional name that resonates most strongly across all of Hampton Roads’ communities.
Envision 2020 said these were the three main takeaways from the marketing situation facing Hampton Roads:The Hampton Roads region doesn’t have a naming issue; it has a marketing issue.

title: Virginia Board of Education report: Teacher shortages, under-funding, and 'persistent achievement gaps' among findings
summary:
NORFOLK, Va. — Teacher shortages, under-funding, and “persistent achievement gaps” are among the problems still lingering in Virginia’s public education system.
That's according to a new report by the Virginia State Board of Education that was presented to Governor Ralph Northam on Sunday.
Norfolk State University’s Dean of Education, Dr. Leon Rouson said the problems have been around for a long time.
“It’s definitely an ongoing issue that I think we’ve been working on for the last decade,” Dr. Rouson said.
“Virginia having very high expectations and I think that very high expectation level has pushed everyone up," Dr. Rouson said.

title: New test results show more 'unacceptable' lead levels in Hampton Roads schools drinking water
summary:
CHESAPEAKE, Va. — Seven Hampton Roads school divisions now report finding water sources with lead levels exceeding EPA recommendations after a review of recent water testing results.
Test results in Newport News show 52 water sources tested for lead levels above 15 parts per billion, the EPA's actionable level.
Documents presented to 13News Now detailing Chesapeake Public Schools' water testing show 114 water sources above 15 ppb.
And now, other Hampton Roads school divisions are detailing their plans for additional water testing, lead level fixes and flushing programs.
Each school division, after sharing its water testing results, said it fixed or removed any water sources testing above 15 ppb.

December 2019 was not only the busiest December in the airport’s history, but it also capped off the busiest year in the airport’s history.

title: Two teens charged after shooting at high school in Norfolk

NORFOLK, Va. – Norfolk detectives have charged two juveniles in connection with a shooting that occurred inside Maury High School.

While investigating the shooting, detectives discovered that another student who was 16-years-old had possession of the firearm after the accidental shooting occurred.
As a result, the 17-year-old has been charged with possession of a firearm on school property, shooting into an occupied school, reckless handling of a firearm, concealed weapon, and possession of a firearm by a minor.
The 16-year-old has been charged with possession of a firearm by a minor and possession of a firearm on school property.

summary:
NORFOLK, Va. – The Virginia State Police responded to a deadly crash involving a van on I-264, east of Military Highway, Thursday morning.
According to police, the crash happened at approximately 9:15 a.m. A white work van traveling eastbound on I-264 struck several vehicles before driving into the jersey wall.
State Police said the driver of the 2005 Chevrolet Express van, 45-year-old Jason Horstman, was traveling eastbound on I-264 when he struck a 1993 Toyota Camry and a 2019 Toyota Avalon, that were also traveling in the eastbound lanes of I-264.
Horstman continued traveling eastbound, driving into a jersey wall, head on.
Horstman died upon impact and police said the driver of the 1993 Toyota Camry suffered non-life threatening injuries and was taken to Norfolk Sentara Hospital.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. — Virginia Beach's Mayor Bobby Dyer has requested a special city council meeting on January 6, 2020, to discuss a resolution that could make the city a Second Amendment sanctuary.
After the special session discussion, the city council will hold a special formal session to take public comment before considering the resolution.
The resolution, if passed, would make the City of Virginia Beach a Second Amendment sanctuary.

summary:

“We had students dealing with personal issues, students dealing with the environment, students dealing with gun violence.”More than 80 students from about a dozen local high schools submitted different forms of art, interpreting the assignment in a number of different ways to create an outlook of hopefulness.

summary:
The octagon will head to Norfolk, Virginia for the second time in 2020, with UFC Norfolk taking place in February.
The UFC is returning to Norfolk, Virginia this February.
In an announcement made Friday, promotion officials revealed that they would head back to the east coast city on February 29, 2020.
The Octagon journeys to the east coast!#UFCNorfolk, we'll see you soon 👊 pic.twitter.com/vjjJjabWnq — UFC (@ufc) December 13, 2019The octagon first visited Norfolk in 2017, when it brought a Fight Night event to town topped by lightweights Dustin Porier vs. Anthony Pettis.
The promotion, in Las Vegas, NV for its final PPV event this year, is coming off a successful UFC on ESPN event in nearby Washington, D.C. this past weekend.

title: Hot list: Five Hampton Roads restaurants to try in December
summary:
The cash-only Yock Nook, a home to fresh-made Chinese noodles inside the Fiber Foods noodle factory in Norfolk, was absent for a while: consider it a hot-weather vacation.
It has returned better than ever, with toothsome noodles made onsite, and a spicy beef broth so deep and rich it’ll make you nostalgic for a grandmother you never even had.
Call ahead to order, and bring cash.

title: Virginia Beach community helps feed and shelter homeless on Christmas Day
summary:
Winter Shelter Christmas 2019 volunteers are helping feed 60 homeless people all week long.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. — Christmas Day is a special time to help others, but all week long the city of Virginia Beach and faith leaders are working together to help the homeless.
It’s in the form of a Winter shelter program, called the Winter Shelter Christmas 2019.
On Christmas morning, volunteers opened the doors at The Gathering at Scott Memorial United Methodist Church, in Virginia Beach.
He and his family found the Winter Shelter Christmas on Facebook.

title: Check out the future of I-64, I-264 corridor
summary:
One rendering from VDOT shows Witchduck Road at I-264 interchange.
VDOT said to improve traffic operations, the Greenwich Road connection at the five-legged intersection at Witchduck Road will be removed.
The new Greenwich Road flyover connects to Cleveland Street near the left corner.
The Newtown Road at Greenwich Road and I-264 rendering shows I-264 extending from the top left corner, with the Newtown Road interchange improvements shown below.
This is where Greenwich Road bisects the image diagonally as it diverges to the new flyover crossing I-264.

title: Cirque du Soleil OVO heads to Norfolk Scope Arena
summary:
Cirque du Soleil OVO is bringing its high-energy show to the Scope Arena starting Friday through Dec. 29.
NORFOLK, Va. — Cirque du Soleil OVO is bringing its high-energy show to the Scope Arena starting Friday through Dec. 29.

title: Three juveniles in custody after leading Chesapeake Police on chase into Norfolk
summary:
CHESAPEAKE, Va. - Three minors are in custody after leading police on a chase from Chesapeake into Norfolk Tuesday afternoon.
Around 1:30 p.m., Chesapeake Police responded to the area of 1500 Sentinel Drive after receiving reports of a stolen white Volvo in the area.
The driver of the vehicle took off, leading officers on a chase that started on I-464 and continued into the Berkeley section of Norfolk.
The driver crashed the vehicle in the area of Wilson Road and E. Indian River Road, where police took three of the vehicle's occupants - all juveniles - into custody.
The Chesapeake Police Department will be handling the incident, and Norfolk Police are no longer involved.
